title: How do I list my Student Loan in my Chapter 13 plan to pay off first before my unsecured creditors?
question: I am filing Chapter 13 Pro Se. I want to pay off my Student loan first before my unsecured creditors. How do I list this in my chapter 13 payment plan? Does it go under unsecured debt? If so, I do I segment it out to get higher priority? Do I list it as a priority, unsecured? I know people have paid their student loans directly during this period. How do I set that up? Since it is the only thing in my plan that is not dischargeable, I would like to pay it first. Also, it will be a cure and maintain account as the amount is $41,000.00
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy repayment plan,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Fees,Representing yourself
answers:
I agree that in a chapter 13 you pay the student loans directly to the lender outside of the plan. You indicate the obligation on the plan, and that it is being paid outside of the plan.

However, the correct place to list the student loans in the bankruptcy petition is on Schedule F. Even though they are non dischargeable, and that they are in a category all of their own, they go on schedule F. If you have any doubt about this, refer to the statistical summary form B6 which has a line for student loand "from schedule F".

Have an attorney do all of this for you. Getting a viable, confirmable plan in compliance with bankruptcy sections 1322 and 1325 is your goal.

I truly wish you the best.

First, student loans are not priority and you cannot make them priority. They are general unsecured debts that are not discharged.

Second, whether they go into the plan or not depends on local practice. If you have the choice, you need to run the numbers both ways. If the debt is in the plan, will the creditor get more money faster than paying it outside the plan? If so, then pay it in the plan. If not, then you need to know what making the payment outside the plan will do to the plan payment. The payment can be considered a long term unsecured debt and be paid outside the plan, but the trustee can still object if a large portion of what would have been your plan payment goes to one unsecured creditor.

If you paying a low percentage to general unsecured creditors, and that payment results in a lower monthly payment to your student loan creditors than you would have paid outside bankruptcy, then try to keep the loan out.

Pay the student loans outside of the plan. Don't put them in plan as they are non dischargable anyway. If you want in the plan they are priority payments but no before secured payments and attorney fee's. Schedule E is where they go. Priority. Again, you can pay outside of the plan.
